bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Tom D. Spies, November 13, 1953

div1.p: Hench informs Spies that he was presented the Finlay Medal in a small ceremony. He comments on the possibility of receiving the Cespedes Medal. It pleases him because he believes one is for his work in cortisone and the other because of his interest in yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Tom D. Spies, November 13, 1953
div1.opener:
November 13, 1953
Dr. Tom D. Spies
Nutrition Clinic
Hillman Hospital
Birmingham, Alabama
My dear Tom:
div1.p:
Yes, they did present the Finlay Medal at a
little ceremony which was rather quickly gotten
together during your nutrition meeting, a cere-
mony that was arranged because Bill Murphy and
I happened to be there, both at the same time.
I can assure you that the ceremony was a very
pleasant one and I was delighted with the honor.

That's why it seems strange to me that I should
be honored further. However who am I to turn
down a beautiful Cuban medal! Seriously,
though, I am very happy about it and it pleases
me especially because I choose to think that one
of these honors came for cortisone and perhaps
the other one came because of my interest in
the yellow fever story. In the latter, I choose
to believe that they think I am dealing fairly
in my handling of Carlos Finlay. I have heard
nothing from the Cuban Government about the new
medal; just from you and, more recently, from
my brother who heard that it was in the NEW YORK
TIMES somewhere.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
